At that time, the powerful brahmin Pure One addressed the Buddha, saying:

In the past, incalculably long eons ago, immeasurable, boundless, and inconceivable,

He thought like this:

He further thought:

Namely, hearing from others and hearing correctly contemplating.

At that time, he gave rise to a mind seeking much learning:

At that time, the householder Pure Power said to the Buddha:

The adornments of giving, pure precepts, and much learning, which of these three adornments is the best?
Which is the most excellent?
The Buddha said:
Pure Power!
Among the three adornments, the adornment of much learning is most praiseworthy, most supreme, unsurpassed, and of the highest excellence.

If one places a single mustard seed next to Mount Sumeru, the merit of giving and the aggregate of pure precepts are also like this, like the mustard seed;
the adornment of much learning is like Mount Sumeru.
Good man!
If a small bird dwells in the sky, the adornments of giving and precepts are also like this;
the adornment of much learning is like the remaining sky.
Good man!
The adornment of giving can accomplish two things.
What are the two?
It can eliminate poverty and accomplish great wealth.
The adornment of pure precepts also accomplishes two things.
What are the two?
One, leaving the evil paths; two, reaching the good realms.
Good man!
The adornment of much learning also accomplishes two things.
What are the two?
It is able to remove all views and gather all the adornments of wisdom.
